headline: Solar stocks climb as some solar imports hit with 3,500% tariffs
summary: Solar stocks and ETFs, like First Solar (FSLR), Sunnova Energy (NOVA), Enphase (ENPH), and Invesco Solar ETF (TAN), are jumping after the US government announced tariffs up to 3,500% on solar panel imports from some Southeast Asian countries. Yahoo Finance Senior Business Reporter Ines Ferré outlines the latest on Market Domination. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

Yahoo Finance Senior Business Reporter Ines Ferré outlines the latest on Market Domination. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: Why Some Tariffs Are Now Above 3,500%
summary: The U.S. just slapped a 3,521% duty on some solar goods from Cambodia—meaning import duties are more than 35 times the cost of the product itself.  That was the steepest levy imposed after a probe into the solar industries of four Southeast Asian countries, namely Cambodia, Malaysia, Thailand and Vietnam.  This marks a win for companies including First Solar (FSLR) that brought the case last year, arguing that Chinese companies operating in Southeast Asia benefit from subsidies that throttle U.S. manufacturing.

raw.headline: Why Some Tariffs Are Now Above 3,500%

headline: First Solar and SolarEdge Shares Are Soaring, What You Need To Know
summary: A number of stocks jumped in the morning session after solar stocks rebounded as the US Commerce Department revealed plans to impose tariffs of up to 3,521% on solar panels imported from Cambodia, Thailand, Malaysia, and Vietnam. What this does is shake up the whole low-cost supply chain that a lot of solar installers and developers have been relying on. Suddenly, importing those panels would be way more expensive, which makes domestically produced panels a lot more attractive.

Suddenly, importing those panels would be way more expensive, which makes domestically produced panels a lot more attractive.

headline: RTX's $850M tariff hit, 3M stock gains, 3,521% solar tariff
summary: Brad Smith examines some of the trading day's trending stories as part of Yahoo Finance's Market Minute. Defense stocks are under pressure after RTX (RTX) warns of an $850 million hit from tariffs despite cost-cutting efforts and some tariff exemptions. Shares of 3M (MMM) pop, lifting the Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI) higher, after the company maintained its full-year outlook despite trade war risks. Solar stocks like First Solar (FSLR), Sunrun (RUN), and SolarEdge (SEDG) are trading higher after the US imposed a large tariff on solar imports from several Southeast Asian countries. Stay up to date on the latest market action, minute-by-minute, with Yahoo Finance's Market Minute.

headline: First Solar Stock Soars on New Tariffs That Hit China-Connected Firms
summary: New tariffs will be imposed by the Commerce Department and the U.S. International Trade Commission (USITC) on foreign solar equipment makers.  The tariffs varies by country and company, but they look likely to be high enough to make American solar equipment cost-competitive.  American solar manufacturers won a major victory in a tariff case announced late on Monday, and some of the stocks were jumping Tuesday.

headline: Latest News In Energy Transition - Complete Solar Delays Results Amid Expanding Solar Ambitions
summary: Complete Solar has announced a delay in reporting its audited financial results for 2024 and unaudited results for the first quarter of 2025, now scheduled for April 30, 2025. This postponement is attributed to the complexities involved in the financial integration of three distinct entities, each with separate accounting systems, following their merging efforts. The company's recent acquisition and consolidation of SunPower assets underscore its expanding role within the residential solar...

headline: First Solar shares rise after U.S. slaps tariffs on Southeast Asian solar imports
summary: Investing.com - Shares in First Solar Inc (NASDAQ:FSLR) rose in premarket trading on Wall Street on Tuesday, after U.S. trade officials slapped steep new tariffs on most solar cells delivered from Southeast Asia.
